4.text:
This is a good day, because, once again, we’re
seeing what’s possible with strong American

11.text:
As I said in my State of the Union address,
ensuring the security of the United States

18.text:
and the safety of our people demands a smart,
patient and disciplined approach to the world.

24.text:
That includes our diplomacy with the Islamic
Republic of Iran.

30.text:
For decades, our differences with Iran meant
that our governments almost never spoke to

36.text:
Ultimately, that did not advance America’s
interests.

41.text:
Over the years, Iran moved closer and closer
to having the ability to build a nuclear weapon.

46.text:
But from Presidents Franklin Roosevelt to
John F. Kennedy to Ronald Reagan, the United

52.text:
States has never been afraid to pursue diplomacy
with our adversaries.

56.text:
And as President, I decided that a strong,
confident America could advance our national

61.text:
security by engaging directly with the Iranian
government.

68.text:
Under the nuclear deal that we, our allies
and partners reached with Iran last year,

74.text: Iran will not get its hands on a nuclear bomb.

79.text:
The region, the United States, and the world
will be more secure.

82.text:
As I’ve said many times, the nuclear deal
was never intended to resolve all of our differences

90.text:
But still, engaging directly with the Iranian
government on a sustained basis, for the first

95.text:
time in decades, has created a unique opportunity
-- a window -- to try to resolve important

103.text:
And today, I can report progress on a number
of fronts.

107.text:
First, yesterday marked a milestone in preventing
Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.

113.text:
Iran has now fulfilled key commitments under
the nuclear deal.

117.text:
And I want to take a moment to explain why
this is so important.

121.text:
Over more than a decade, Iran had moved ahead
with its nuclear program, and, before the

125.text:
deal, it had installed nearly 20,000 centrifuges
that can enrich uranium for a nuclear bomb.

132.text:
Today, Iran has removed two-thirds of those
machines.

136.text:
Before the deal, Iran was steadily increasing
its stockpile of enriched uranium -- enough

145.text:
Today, more than 98 percent of that stockpile
has been shipped out of Iran -- meaning Iran

150.text:
now doesn’t have enough material for even
one bomb.

156.text:
Before, Iran was nearing completion of a new
reactor capable of producing plutonium for

163.text:
Today, the core of that reactor has been pulled
out and filled with concrete so it cannot

170.text:
Before the deal, the world had relatively
little visibility into Iran’s nuclear program.

175.text:
Today, international inspectors are on the
ground, and Iran is being subjected to the

180.text:
most comprehensive, intrusive inspection regime
ever negotiated to monitor a nuclear program.

187.text:
Inspectors will monitor Iran’s key nuclear
facilities 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.

194.text:
For decades to come, inspectors will have
access to Iran’s entire nuclear supply chain.

200.text:
In other words, if Iran tries to cheat -- if
they try to build a bomb covertly -- we will

208.text: So the bottom line is this.

209.text:
Whereas Iran was steadily expanding its nuclear
program, we have now cut off every single

214.text:
path that Iran could have used to build a
bomb.

219.text:
Whereas it would have taken Iran two to three
months to break out with enough material to

223.text:
rush to a bomb, we’ve now extended that
breakout time to a year -- and with the world’s

230.text:
unprecedented inspections and access to Iran’s
program, we’ll know if Iran ever tries to

238.text:
Now that Iran’s actions have been verified,
it can begin to receive relief from certain

243.text:
nuclear sanctions and gain access to its own
money that had been frozen.

248.text:
And perhaps most important of all, we’ve
achieved this historic progress through diplomacy,

254.text:
without resorting to another war in the Middle
East.

257.text:
I want to also point out that by working with
Iran on this nuclear deal, we were better

267.text:
When our sailors in the Persian Gulf accidentally
strayed into Iranian waters that could have

275.text:
Some folks here in Washington rushed to declare
that it was the start of another hostage crisis.

280.text:
Instead, we worked directly with the Iranian
government and secured the release of our

288.text:
This brings me to a second major development
-- several Americans unjustly detained by

296.text:
In some cases, these Americans faced years
of continued detention.

301.text: And I’ve met with some of their families.

304.text:
I’ve seen their anguish, how they ache for
their sons and husbands.

308.text:
I gave these families my word -- I made a
vow -- that we would do everything in our

314.text: power to win the release of their loved ones.

318.text:
On the sidelines of the nuclear negotiations,
our diplomats at the highest level, including

323.text:
Secretary Kerry, used every meeting to push
Iran to release our Americans.

328.text:
I did so myself, in my conversation with President
Rouhani.

333.text:
After the nuclear deal was completed, the
discussions between our governments accelerated.

338.text:
Yesterday, these families finally got the
news that they have been waiting for.

347.text:
A courageous journalist for The Washington
Post, who wrote about the daily lives and

352.text:
hopes of the Iranian people, he’s been held
for a year and a half.

356.text:
He embodies the brave spirit that gives life
to the freedom of the press.

362.text:
Jason has already been reunited with his wife
and mom.

367.text: Pastor Saeed Abedini is coming home.

372.text:
Held for three and half years, his unyielding
faith has inspired people around the world

377.text: in the global fight to uphold freedom of religion.

379.text:
Now, Pastor Abedini will return to his church
and community in Idaho.

387.text:
A former sergeant in the Marine Corps, he’s
been held for four and a half years.

393.text:
Today, his parents and sisters are giving
thanks in Michigan.

398.text:
Two other Americans unjustly detained by Iran
have also been released -- Nosratollah Khosravi-Roodsari

407.text:
and Matthew Trevithick, an Iranian -- who
was in Iran as a student.

413.text: Their cases were largely unknown to the world.

415.text:
But when Americans are freed and reunited
with their families, that’s something that

419.text:
So I want to thank my national security team
-- especially Secretary Kerry; Susan Rice,

427.text:
my National Security Advisor; Brett McGurk;
Avril Haines; Ben Rhodes -- our whole team

436.text:
worked tirelessly to bring our Americans home,
to get this work done.

443.text:
And I want to thank the Swiss government,
which represents our interests in Iran, for

448.text:
And meanwhile, Iran has agreed to deepen our
coordination as we work to locate Robert Levinson

455.text: -- missing from Iran for more than eight years.

458.text:
Even as we rejoice in the safe return of others,
we will never forget about Bob.

463.text:
Each and every day, but especially today,
our hearts are with the Levinson family, and

466.text:
we will not rest until their family is whole
again.

471.text:
In a reciprocal humanitarian gesture, six
Iranian–Americans and one Iranian serving

476.text:
sentences or awaiting trial in the United
States are being granted clemency.

481.text:
These individuals were not charged with terrorism
or any violent offenses.

485.text:
They’re civilians, and their release is
a one-time gesture to Iran given the unique

491.text:
opportunity offered by this moment and the
larger circumstances at play.

495.text:
And it reflects our willingness to engage
with Iran to advance our mutual interests,

499.text:
even as we ensure the national security of
the United States.

511.text:
The third piece of this work that we got done
this weekend involved the United States and

518.text:
Iran resolving a financial dispute that dated
back more than three decades.

524.text:
Since 1981, after our nations severed diplomatic
relations, we’ve worked through a international

529.text:
tribunal to resolve various claims between
our countries.

533.text:
The United States and Iran are now settling
a longstanding Iranian government claim against

541.text:
Iran will be returned its own funds, including
appropriate interest, but much less than the

548.text:
For the United States, this settlement could
save us billions of dollars that could have

554.text:
So there was no benefit to the United States
in dragging this out.

558.text:
With the nuclear deal done, prisoners released,
the time was right to resolve this dispute

566.text:
Of course, even as we implement the nuclear
deal and welcome our Americans home, we recognize

574.text:
that there remain profound differences between
the United States and Iran.

580.text:
We remain steadfast in opposing Iran’s destabilizing
behavior elsewhere, including its threats

585.text:
against Israel and our Gulf partners, and
its support for violent proxies in places

592.text:
We still have sanctions on Iran for its violations
of human rights, for its support of terrorism,

599.text: and for its ballistic missile program.

600.text:
And we will continue to enforce these sanctions,
vigorously.

604.text:
Iran’s recent missile test, for example,
was a violation of its international obligations.

610.text:
And as a result, the United States is imposing
sanctions on individuals and companies working

615.text: to advance Iran’s ballistic missile program.

619.text:
And we are going to remain vigilant about
it.

620.text:
We're not going to waver in the defense of
our security or that of our allies and partners.

625.text:
But I do want to once again speak directly
to the Iranian people.

632.text:
Yours is a great civilization, with a vibrant
culture that has so much to contribute to

636.text:
the world -- in commerce, and in science and
the arts.

641.text:
For decades, your government’s threats and
actions to destabilize your region have isolated

645.text: Iran from much of the world.

648.text:
And now our governments are talking with one
another.

652.text:
Following the nuclear deal, you -- especially
young Iranians -- have the opportunity to

657.text: begin building new ties with the world.

661.text:
We have a rare chance to pursue a new path
-- a different, better future that delivers

666.text:
progress for both our peoples and the wider
world.

669.text:
That’s the opportunity before the Iranian
people.

673.text: We need to take advantage of that.

675.text:
And to my fellow Americans, today, we’re
united in welcoming home sons and husbands

681.text:
and brothers who, in lonely prison cells,
have endured an absolute nightmare.

686.text:
But they never gave in and they never gave
up.

688.text:
At long last, they can stand tall and breathe
deep the fresh air of freedom.

693.text:
As a nation, we face real challenges, around
the world and here at home.

701.text:
Many of them will not be resolved quickly
or easily.

705.text:
But today’s progress -- Americans coming
home, an Iran that has rolled back its nuclear

710.text:
program and accepted unprecedented monitoring
of that program -- these things are a reminder

716.text:
of what we can achieve when we lead with strength
and with wisdom; with courage and resolve

726.text:
America can do -- and has done -- big things
when we work together.

731.text:
We can leave this world and make it safer
and more secure for our children and our grandchildren

741.text:
I want to thank once again Secretary Kerry;
our entire national security team, led by

747.text:
I'm grateful for all the assistance that we
received from our allies and partners.

754.text:
And I am hopeful that this signals the opportunity
at least for Iran to work more cooperatively

763.text:
with nations around the world to advance their
interests and the interests of people who

771.text:
are looking for peace and security for their
families.

777.text:
God bless you, and God bless the United States
of America.
